awd_titl_txt: CAREER: SusChEM: Iron Catalysts for the Reduction of Amides
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Michael Findlater of the Department of Chemistry at Texas Tech University is developing sustainable catalysts based upon the earth abundant transition metals. Chemical catalysis is used to produce many commodity chemicals in the pharmaceutical, construction, communication and food industries and thus, is a fundamental economic driver for the U.S. economy. However, many of the most importance catalytic transformations rely on expensive and rare metal elements.  These rare metals currently provide a critical need in catalytic chemistry. To meet this challenge, new catalysts based on less toxic and earth abundant elements are being designed and synthesized as replacements for the precious metal elements currently in use.  An outreach program developed by Professor Findlater involves the development of traveling Labs which focus on catalysis. The labs are designed for portability to allow transport to rural area high schools; allowing the students the means to learn about catalysis. 

This project focuses on new environmentally benign catalysts based on diimine complexes of iron, as well as the study of the varied mechanisms at play in iron catalysis. Various catalyst structures are being examined, and the most promising ones are being studied further using X-ray crystallography, paramagnetic NMR spectroscopy, Mössbauer spectroscopy and detailed kinetic analyses. The broader impacts of this work include potential societal benefits from the discovery of catalysts from less toxic, earth abundant metals and new insight into the reaction chemistry of first-row transition metals.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits

One of the central hypotheses in our NSF CAREER proposal is that the redox non-innocent BIAN (bis(arylimino)acenaphthene) ligand could be engaged as a supporting framework in iron-based catalysts. We found that the incorporation of BIAN ligands into a range of iron- and cobalt-based complexes resulted in highly active catalysts employing first row metals. These complexes were examined for a number of catalytic reactions, including hydroboration, hydrosilylation, alkyne trimerization and alkylation of a range of unsaturated substrates. Our mechanistic studies showed that the spin-state of the metal is important to achieve rapid catalytic rates by affording access to lower energy pathways which would be impossible if limited to diamagnetic species.

During efforts to expand on this chemistry we pursued two new directions: i) electrochemically driving organic reactions using cobalt and nickel catalysts and, ii) recovery of transition metal catalysts and their reuse in subsquent reactions. Our strategy of tying ligand design closely to subsequent mechanistic understanding has allowed us to rapidly advance our understanding of catalyst recycling.

Broader Impacts

The NSF CAREER grant has involved the training of several graduate students, undergraduates and postdoctoral scholars. All of the graduate students supported by the CAREER grant have gone on to teaching positions or have secured roles in industry, inluding most recently a position with INTEL. These students were trained in the synthesis of organic, inorganic and organometallics species and their application in catalytic and mechanistic chemistry. ur research has uncovered a wealth of new design principles for the application of transition metal complexes with redox non-innocent ligands in reductive chemistry. Many of these design pribciples were described in a recent Perspective Article in the European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry. Furthermore, our recent new directions in electroorganic synthesis have recently been described in two new perspective articles in Chemistry A European Journal and ACS Catalysis.

Another focus of the NSF CAREER grant included the development of a mutli-investigator and multi-institution virtual networking group: ORDMOC (Online Research Discussion in Mechanistic Organometallic Chemistry). Following a multi-year effort, the group expanded to a diverse set of investigators and institutions at Carnegie Mellon, DePaul, Texas Christian Universty, Worcester Polytechnic Institute, West Virginia University, Southern Methodist University, Temple University and The College of New Jersey. Numerous undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral scientists presented their work. Moreover, several publications have now emerged between two or more research groups within ORDMOC. 


Last Modified: 07/31/2023
Modified by: Michael Findlater
